results.title: The Three little pigs (K)
results.creator_credit: Jan Mack, Paul R. Gagne and Weston Woods Studios
results.brief_description: The legendary story of the three pigs and the greedy, scheming wolf comes to glorious “huffing, puffing” life as the wolf tries his best to outsmart the pigs and at last meets his comeuppance. This favourite story features a lively narration by Ian Thompson. Based on the book by Erik Blegvad.

results.title: The Three fools and the foolish woman
results.creator_credit: Donyo Donev, Animated Cartoon Studio and Boyana Film
results.brief_description: In this animated film the three fools are in the company of a representative of the weaker sex. However as far as her brainpower is concerned, the spectator soon realises that she belongs to their category. They court her in the most stupid possible way bearing out the old truth that even the fool’s love is always foolish.

results.title: The Three blind mice
results.brief_description: This animated film illustrates why industrial safety rules must be observed. The nursery rhyme favorites prove no less foolish in the factory than when they provoked reprisal from the farmer’s wife. They disobey all the safety rules with dire results.
results.description: This animated film illustrates why industrial safety rules must be observed. The nursery rhyme favorites prove no less foolish in the factory than when they provoked reprisal from the farmer’s wife. They disobey all the safety rules with dire results.

results.title: The Three A's
results.creator_credit: Central Office of Information and Great Britain. Ministry of Education
results.brief_description: One of the principles introduced into education in Great Britain as a result of the New Education Act of 1944 is that of stressing the three A’s rather than the traditional three R’s; the three A’s are - age, ability, and aptitude, of each individual pupil. By considering these three A’s, teachers and parents are better able to provide for each child the type of education most suited to their needs. The aim of education becomes the co-ordination of classroom and practical experience, so that children learn to apply their knowledge and skills to the demands of everyday life.
